awd_titl_txt: Plasma-Surface Interactions at Low Ion Energies
awd_abstract_narration:
Plasmas are gas-phase assemblies of ions, electrons, and neutral molecules/atoms. When materials surfaces are exposed to plasmas, many complex physical and chemical interactions take place. In particular, energetic ions can dislodge violently, interact electronically, or form chemical bonds with surface atoms. The formation and breakage of chemical bonds (reactions) between energetic gas-phase ions and surfaces are very poorly understood. This research is focused in improving the understanding of such reaction mechanisms and controlling the outcome of plasma-surface interactions. The experimental results will stimulate the development and testing of relevant theories, and introduce new knowledge on reactive scattering dynamics into chemical curricula.

Findings from this research should impact surface science and plasma processing, important technologies for characterizing and treating, coating, or etching solid surfaces for applications ranging from surface functionalization, to microelectronics fabrication, and space exploration. The research should lead to a new paradigm for selecting plasma chemistries and conditions, based on the reactivity and overall scattering dynamics of specific ions formed in the plasma, thus speeding up and making less expensive the development of plasma processes for many applications.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

A. Intellectual Merit

This project has produced new knowledge for two uncommon classes of chemical reactions at surfaces, which are driven by energetic molecules. The first class encompasses Eley-Rideal reactions, which occur when the energetic molecules collide with surfaces where they combine with other species to form new molecules. These collisional reactions are not catalytic, are independent of surface temperature, and can be tailored by the kinetic energy of the incident molecule. The project produced definitive proof that Eley-Rideal reactions do occur, determined the range of energies required, and established ways to predict the chemical identity and energy of the new molecules produced. The second class encompasses intramolecular reactions, which occur within a molecule during or after an energetic collision with a surface. These reactions are unusual because they produce unexpected combinations of the atoms in the colliding molecule. We have discovered that water molecules can break down into molecular hydrogen and atomic oxygen, effectively splitting water in single collisions with generic surfaces. Likewise, carbon dioxide can breakdown directly into molecular oxygen, providing a surprising new way to remediate this pollutant gas. Basic understanding of these reactions improves curricula on chemical dynamics and enhances our ability to explain observations in plasma processing environments and astrophysical systems, where energetic ions are encountered.

 

B. Broader Impact

Dynamic reactions of energetic water molecules colliding with cometary nuclei and other planetary surfaces have not been considered before as means of chemical transformation in astrophysics. But water molecules moving at high speeds can drive oxidation in extremely cold environments. Results from this project demonstrate unexpected new pathways to produce molecules found in astrophysical environments, whose origin was previously a puzzle. For example, the abundant molecular oxygen, discovered in the coma of comet 67P by the Rosetta mission, may originate in water ion collisions with cometary surfaces, explaining the observations without invoking primordial of biotic pathways. Similar mechanisms can also lead to the formation of small organic molecules, such as methanol, thereby altering the perception of what is a biomarker molecule in space. Our results suggest that energetic ions may provide energy to chemically modify ices in extreme astrophysical conditions, which may provide clues to the origin of life.

 

During this project, it was discovered that collisions of carbon dioxide molecules with generic surfaces (metals, oxides) at certain high speeds cause the molecules to split into carbon and molecular oxygen very efficiently. This process will facilitate designing a plasma-based oxygenator to produce molecular oxygen for future space travel and for colonizing Mars.
